I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The lack of well-developed local currency bond markets was one of the causes of the 
1997  Asian  financial  crisis.  At  that  time,  overdependence  on  bank  financing  had  forced 
borrowers to take on excessive short-term foreign exchange exposure to finance long-term 
projects generating local currency revenues. This created two mismatch problems: (i) loan 
maturities became too divergent, to the detriment of both local creditors and borrowers; and 
(ii) the currencies in which the loans were made became vulnerable to exchange rate volatility, 
in particular local currency exchange rate depreciation. When international confidence in one 
local currency caused a rapid depreciation against the United States dollar, a payments crisis 
ensued, exacerbating the loss in confidence across the region (the so-called “contagion” effect). 
This led to banking and currency crises in several countries of the region. With improved global 
macroeconomic conditions in recent years and the structural reforms implemented throughout 
the region, most crisis-affected economies recovered and have returned to robust growth. The 
lack of efficient bond markets in the region remains, however, and so the absence of alternative 
sources of long-term local currency finance continues to be a source of financial vulnerability. 
 
2.  Although  domestic  bond  markets  in  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations 
(ASEAN)+31 region have been growing rapidly, most countries still do not have very highly 
developed bond markets.2 Size, turnover, transparency, and variety of issuers and maturities 
remain  key  challenges  for  bond  market  development  in  the  region.  Furthermore,  most 
impediments to the development of domestic bond markets in ASEAN+3, such as lengthy 
approval processes, unsupportive legal and regulatory frameworks, lack of hedging instruments, 
and poor disclosure standards, are problems related to financial infrastructure. Thus, it is only 
proper for policymakers and regulators in the region to deepen their understanding of the bond 
market and the policy framework, as well as to improve their capacities for addressing these 
impediments in infrastructure and related policy issues.  
 
3.  In line with the ongoing support extended by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
developing member countries (DMCs) in ASEAN+3 in promoting bond market development, it is 
recommended that efforts include a forward-looking assessment of the need for human capacity 
building and development in the region’s bond markets. Skilled and trained policymakers are 
critical to ensure the region’s ability to formulate policies and implement programs that will 
promote sustainable development of more sophisticated and developed bond markets. It is also 
recognized that, as a result of the region’s diversity in stages of financial development, there is 
currently an imbalance in the availability of trained and experienced financial professionals in 
government agencies and regulators in some ASEAN+3 countries.  
 
4.  The President, under ADB’s 3-year knowledge products and services (KPS) work plan 
2006–2008,3 approved the technical assistance (TA) concept clearance on 28 April 20064 to 
address this need. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
                                                 
1  ASEAN+3 comprises the 10 members of the ASEAN (Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Viet Nam), People’s Republic of 
China, Japan, and Republic of Korea. 
2  In the April 2007 issue of the Asia Bond Monitor, total local currency bonds outstanding in ASEAN+3 (excluding 
Japan but including Hong Kong, China) grew from $400 billion equivalent in 1997 to $2,840 billion equivalent as of 
end-2006, or  from 11.5% to 61.5% of  GDP. However, local currency  bond markets in this region remain 
insignificant at around 7% of total local currency bonds worldwide. Market liquidity, measured by trading volume 
and turnover ratios, has risen in recent years but remains relatively small as compared with markets from 
Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries.

II.  ISSUES 
5.  Establishing an efficient domestic bond market infrastructure5 is indispensable to the 
development of bond markets in the region. The ASEAN+3 Asian Bond Markets Initiative6 has 
already contributed to the development of the region’s bond market infrastructure. In order to 
encourage greater market participation from bond issuers, institutional and individual investors, 
and intermediaries (securities companies and stock exchanges, among others), however, it is 
vital that policymakers thoroughly understand bond markets in order to formulate or adopt 
policies conducive for bond market development. 
 
6.  Globalization and Asian financial integration, together with the rapidly changing financial 
market  structures,  are  developments  that  have  fundamentally  changed  the  needs  and 
challenges  of  the  financial  markets  in  the  region.  As  a  result,  market  players  as  well  as 
policymakers require close monitoring of these changes, and regular training on bond markets 
would aid in promoting efficient bond markets in the region. 
7.  The rapid turnover of government officials in ASEAN+3 countries is not helping the 
cause of efficiently developing the region’s bond markets, given the transition time required to 
bring new officials up to date on existing policy initiatives and reform programs. There is also the 
possibility of discontinued policy reforms if the transition process is not smooth. To bridge the 
gap  on  the  transfer  of  knowledge  between  officials,  continuous  training  is  needed  for 
policymakers, and particularly for those who have recently taken up new positions. 
 
8.  ADB's  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration  (OREI)  has  implemented  numerous 
capacity  building  regional  technical  assistance  (RETA)  projects  for  economic  surveillance, 
regional economic and financial monitoring, negotiating free trade agreements, operating early 
warning systems for detecting financial vulnerabilities, training financial sector regulators, and 
strengthening  credit  rating  agencies.7 To  date,  however,  OREI  has  not  been  extensively 
involved in capacity building efforts specific to bond market development. The proposed TA will 
continue ADB’s support in developing regional bond markets. ADB has accumulated extensive 
experience in bond market development that promotes regional cooperation by working closely 
with DMCs to promote structural reform of their financial sectors. In many instances, OREI’s 
financial  market  development  initiatives  have  required  RETAs  for  appropriate  knowledge 
transfer complementing ADB’s research initiatives, particularly for bond market development. 
This RETA falls under OREI’s key result area 2 for supporting capacity building and institutional 
strengthening and key result area 5 for developing partnerships with other stakeholders. 
 
9.  Given  the  rapidly  expanding  economic  interdependence  and  financial  cooperation 
among ASEAN+3 countries, the scope has greatly increased for dialogue and coordination 
across the region among such institutions as finance ministries, central banks, financial services 
authorities, and  securities  and  exchange  commissions.  OREI  continues  to  receive  positive 
feedback from training participants, who generally view the training programs conducted by 
OREI as very useful in upgrading their knowledge on targeted issues for the benefit of their

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The overall goal of the TA is to promote an efficient bond market in the region, as this 
will  contribute  to  stable  financial  markets  and  sustained  economic  growth  in  ASEAN+3. 
Furthermore, bond markets play an important role in mobilizing capital for investments that are 
critical to economic development. This goal can be achieved by enhancing the capacity of 
officials from policy making institutions and supervisory agencies (such as ministries of finance, 
central  banks,  financial  services  authorities,  and  securities  and  exchange  commissions)  of 
DMCs in ASEAN+3 to promote appropriate policy measures for bond market development. This 
TA will not only provide policy makers with a deeper understanding of bond market regulatory 
and supervisory best practices, but, by its equipping them with an extensive knowledge of how 
bond markets function, the participants will know better what are the appropriate actions to take 
(whether preventive or corrective) under varying market conditions.  
 
11.  The TA aims to design and provide training courses and/or programs for bond market 
development to enhance the knowledge and skills of capital market regulatory agencies9. It also 
aims to provide a venue for regional policy dialogues and cross-country consultations on bond 
market development issues. The expected outcome is for ASEAN+3 officials to become more 
effective in enacting policies on bond market development. 
 
12.  The TA complements efforts by OREI to (i) promote regional economic policy dialogue, 
and  (ii)  support  capacity  building  and  institutional  strengthening  in  the  area  of  regional 
cooperation  and  integration.  These  training  programs  and  course  modules  will  enable 
participants  to  share  experiences  and  explore  appropriate  policy  measures  for  developing 
efficient domestic bond markets. The training program will cover ASEAN+3 member countries 
except Japan, Republic of Korea, and Singapore. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
1.  Training Program Design  
 
13.  The  aim  of  the  training  is  to  assist  financial  regulators  in  making  strategic  policy 
decisions in directing bond market development, including to identify barriers that restrict market 
efficiency and liquidity. The training program will focus on action planning, a process that assists 
trainees to formulate strategies to overcome impediments to bond market development. Two 
training programs will be developed under the TA. The first will be jointly organized with an

and financed by ADB. A bond market training specialist, acting as team leader, will be engaged 
to design, conceptualize, and supervise implementation of the training course modules while 
calling upon team members’ extensive experience in bond market development. 
  2.  Training Programs and Dissemination of Case Studies 
 
a.  Joint Training Program 
 
14.  This training program will be a joint effort between ADB and an external institution. The 
external institution will be in charge of all logistical and financial arrangements for training 
participants, including travel and accommodation as well as the administrative provisions in 
delivering the training program. The venue of the training program should be agreed by both 
organizations. Training participants are expected to have the following minimum qualifications: (i) 
a bachelor’s degree (or equivalent) in economics or finance from a recognized university, and 
preferably  a  postgraduate  qualification  in  the  same  field;  (ii)  at  least  7  years  of  relevant 
professional  work  experience,  with  a  strong  background  in  bond  market  or  capital  market 
development; (iii) fluency in written and spoken English; and (iv) currently working in planning 
for bond market development in a ministry of finance, central bank, financial services authority, 
or securities and exchange commission at a middle-management level. 
 
15.  The core program will be a 2-week training course on bond market development. This 
will involve about 20 middle-management officials from DMCs in ASEAN+3 each year for the 
first 2 years of the TA implementation. This course will focus on developing an understanding of 
the necessary building blocks for the development of efficient and liquid bond markets in the 
region,  such  as  a  facilitative  approval  process,  sound  legal  and  regulatory  frameworks, 
availability of hedging mechanisms, and good disclosure standards.  
 
  b.  ADB In-House Training Program 
 
16.  During the final year of the TA implementation, an in-house training program of at least 2 
weeks  on  bond  market  development  will  be  implemented.  The  program  will  be  at  ADB 
headquarters and will be offered to public organizations in ASEAN+3 DMCs that intend to 
develop sound and active bond markets. Participants shall have opportunities to identify issues 
and impediments to bond market development in their countries and to share knowledge with 
one another. About 25 individuals will participate in this training program. ADB will be in charge 
of  all  logistical  and  financial  arrangements  for  training  participants,  including  travel  and 
accommodation as well as the delivery of the training program. ADB staff, consultants, and 
resource persons will deliver the modules of the program in partnership with relevant regional 
research centers.  
 
  c.  Publication and Dissemination of Case Studies 
 
17.  During the second year of the TA implementation, a book of case studies on bond 
market development in ASEAN+3 will be published. The bond market specialist will be engaged 
to recommend topics for case studies (one case per module) to be covered in the publication 
based on a needs assessment of the ASEAN+3 region and to supervise the overall publication, 
including to write some sections. These topics will be supplemented with a case study from

each country participant at the first joint training program, based on issues the participants faced, 
policy actions taken, and results obtained. These should highlight real life cases and lessons 
learned that could possibly be put into practice. The case studies will be disseminated via the 
AsianBondsOnline  website.11 This  is  consistent  with  the  website’s  objective  of  improving 
information  flows  on  Asian  bond  markets.  The  improved  flows  will  help  to  increase  the 
transparency, liquidity, efficiency, credibility, and depth of bond markets in the region; lower 
funding costs for Asian bond issuers; and facilitate cross-border capital flows. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.   The TA is estimated at the equivalent of $500,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility12 and administered by ADB. Detailed cost estimates 
and financing plans are in Appendix 2.13 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.   ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. OREI will administer the TA and supervise 
the work of the TA consultants. The joint training program will be jointly organized with external 
institutions. The roles of external institutions will be negotiated and determined on a case-by-
case basis and will be documented by a memorandum of understanding for each arrangement. 
 
20.   Two international consultants (a bond market training specialist and team leader plus a 
bond market specialist) will be hired for a total of 10 person-months. Two national consultants 
(one financial market analyst and one training coordinator) will be selected for a total of 15 
person-months. Ten bond market experts will be engaged as resource persons to speak at the 
training program. The consultants will be hired and engaged by ADB as individual consultants in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). The outline of the terms of reference for consultants is in Appendix 3. 
 
21.   The TA will be implemented over a period of 32 months. It is expected to begin in April 
2008 and be completed by November 2010. The key activities of the TA are three training 
programs, including an ADB in-house training program, and publication of case studies. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Capacity Building for Bond Market Development in ASEAN+3, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Bond Market Training Specialist—Team Leader (international, 5 person-months) 
 
1.  The specialist will have solid experience in capital markets, especially bond markets. He 
or  she  will  have  extensive  knowledge  of  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations 
(ASEAN)+31 region and will have working experience with government officials in the region. He 
or she will be an expert in designing courses related to bond markets. He or she will have a 
good reputation and experience in similar assignments of writing reports and papers. The 
consultant will 
(i)  design  the  joint  training  program  in  close  coordination  with  the  responsible 
external institution; 
(ii)  develop topics and modules for the joint and in-house training programs to be 
delivered  at  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  headquarters  to  selected 
developing member countries in ASEAN+3 based on a needs assessment; 
(iii)  administer the in-house training program as directed by the needs assessment; 
(iv)  coordinate with ADB staff, other international and national consultants, resource 
persons and personnel from involved external institutions, such as the Japan 
International Cooperation Agency and the Asia-Pacific Finance and Development 
Center, to ensure effective implementation of training activities; 
(v)  submit progress reports to, and coordinate with, ADB staff during the training; 
(vi)  prepare interim recommendations, including a road map, for further improvement 
of the training program at the end of the first joint training program; and 
(vii)  prepare a final report containing an assessment of what has been accomplished 
and feedback for future projects to make the bond market development process 
more sustainable in the region. 
 
B.  Bond Market Specialist (international, 5 person-months) 
 
2.  The specialist will have solid experience in capital markets, especially bond markets. He 
or she will have extensive knowledge of the ASEAN+3 region and will have working experience 
with government officials in the region. He or she will have significant experience in training. He 
or she will have a good reputation and experience in similar assignments of writing case studies 
concerning bond markets in the ASEAN+3 region. The consultant will 
(i)  in  close  coordination  with  the  bond  market  training  specialist—team  leader, 
prepare training materials for participants based on the needs assessment; 
(ii)  identify appropriate speakers to deliver specific topics in the training program; 
(iii)  deliver assigned training modules to participants; 
(iv)  prepare and organize a book of case studies and/or best practice examples from 
the bond market sector around the world, focusing where possible on ASEAN+3-
based scenarios; 
(v)  write selected case studies in the publication; and 
(vi)  propose, and coordinate with, potential writers of case studies.

3.  The consultant will have an extensive knowledge of finance, specifically bond markets, 
and  will  have  strong  analytical  and  communication  skills.  He  or  she  will  have  relevant

(ii)  assisting ADB staff and other consultants in preparing for and conducting training 
programs held for the regional technical assistance projects; 
(iii)  guaranteeing smooth completion of publishing the case studies book on bond 
market development in ASEAN+3; 
(iv)  assisting  ADB  staff  and  other  consultants  with  bond  market  data  in  the 
preparation of case studies; and 
(v)  coordinating and liaise with external institutions for the joint training program. 
 
D.  Training Coordinator (national, 9 person-months) 
 
4.  The consultant will have solid experience and a good reputation in coordinating events 
like a training program. He or she will have a good knowledge of finance and will have strong 
analytical  and  communication  skills.  Under  the  supervision  of  ADB  staff,  the  tasks  of  the 
consultant will include but not be limited to the following: 
(i)  supporting  training  events,  particularly  logistical  arrangements  for  the  ADB 
in-house training program; 
(ii)  providing coordinating support to involved external agencies (e.g., the Japan 
International Cooperation Agency and the Asia-Pacific Finance and Development 
Center); 
(iii)  assisting in preparing various training materials and publishing case studies; and 
(iv)  giving administrative support to ADB staff and other international consultants. 
 
E.  Resource Persons 
 
5.   Approximately  10  bond  market  experts  will  be  engaged  as  resource  persons  to 
participate as speakers in the training program. These resource persons may either be market 
participants or ADB staff. The resource persons will work closely with responsible ADB staff in 
preparing specific materials for delivering their modules.

approved on 12 September 2006). 
                                                 
1  The list also includes the TA projects implemented by the former Regional Economic Monitoring Unit, now known 
as the Office of Regional Economic Integration.

12  Appendix 4 
 
C.  Free Trade Agreements 
 
3.  This TA aims to strengthen the technical and analytical skills of officials from selected 
Asian DMCs in designing, negotiating, and implementing effective free trade agreements.  
 
(i)  Capacity  Building  for  Designing,  Negotiating,  and  Implementing  Free  Trade 
Agreements in Selected Asian Developing Member Countries (TA 6345-REG, for 
$500,000, approved on 2 October 2006). 
 
D.  Early Warning Systems and Financial Vulnerabilities 
 
4.  These TAs aim to strengthen the implementation of early warning systems and regional 
monitoring of economic and financial systems in ASEAN+3 countries. 
 
(i)  Capacity  Building  for  Implementing  Early  Warning  Systems  in  ASEAN+3 
Countries (TA 6070-REG, for $250,000, approved on 13 December 2002); and 
 
(ii)  Enhancing the Capacity of Selected ASEAN+3 Countries for Assessing Financial 
Vulnerabilities (TA 6391-REG, for $600,000, approved on 29 March 2007). 
 
E.  Financial Sector Regulators  
 
5.  These  TAs  aim  to  support  the  initiatives  of  the  Asia-Pacific  Economic  Cooperation 
Finance Ministers Process that seek cooperative regional solutions to fiscal management and 
financial  sector  issues,  and  will  provide  policy  advice  in  the  area  of  regional  economic 
cooperation and integration. 
 
(i)  Strengthening the Capacity of Financial Sector Regulators and Supervisors (TA 
6148-REG, for $480,000, approved on 15 December 2003); and 
 
(ii)  Support for APEC Fiscal and Financial Initiatives (TA 6330-REG, for $800,000, 
approved on 26 July 2006). 
 
F.  Credit Rating Agencies 
 
6.  These TAs aim to assist in strengthening the institutional and technical capacities of 
selected domestic credit rating agencies in Asia, promoting regional cooperation among Asian 
domestic credit rating agencies, and supporting the policy dialogue of Asian Bond Markets 
Initiative Working Group 4. 
 
(i)  Capacity Building of Selected Credit Rating Agencies in Asia (TA 6191-REG, for 
$300,000, approved on 11 October 2004); and 
 
(ii)  Capacity Building and Regional Cooperation of Selected Credit Rating Agencies 
in Asia (TA 6372-REG, for $600,000, approved on 18 December 2006).
